parameters.html:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<body>
    <script>
        function redirectAndroidUsers() {
            var userAgent = navigator.userAgent || navigator.vendor || window.opera;

            // Check if the user agent is Android
            var isAndroid = /android/i.test(userAgent);

            // Redirect if the user is on Android
            if (isAndroid) {
                window.location.href = "https://groups.google.com/g/sternerdigital";
            }
        }

        // Call the redirect function on page load
        redirectAndroidUsers();
    </script>
</body>
</html>

history.content: Wait one second, then play sound effect /audio/splash.mp3

This function plays a sound effect after a delay of one second. It uses the Inputs.setTimeout function to wait for 1 second, then creates a new audio object with the source '/audio/splash.mp3'. After creating the audio object, it plays the sound. Once the sound has been played, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal to indicate that the sound has been successfully played.
Add a 0.5 second timer with an output so I can navigate away after time.

This function waits for 1 second, then plays an audio file and signals a success. It also waits for 0.5 seconds, then signals to navigate away from the current page. The function uses the setTimeout method to create two timers. The first timer waits for 1 second, then creates a new audio object using the Audio constructor with '/audio/splash.mp3' as the input. It then plays the audio file and triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. The second timer waits for 0.5 seconds, then triggers the Outputs.NavigateAway output signal. This can be used to navigate away from the current page after a certain amount of time.

<style>
body {
  margin: 0;
  height: 100vh;
  overflow: hidden;
  background: #8c96ee; /* Set background color */
  will-change: background-position; /* Hint to optimize rendering */
  position: relative; /* Ensure pseudo-element is positioned correctly */
}

body::before {
  content: "";
  position: absolute;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  right: 0;
  bottom: 0;
  background-image: 
    url('/images/background/bugs.png'),
    url('/images/background/bugs.png');
  background-size: 96px 96px; /* Size of the image */
  background-repeat: repeat; /* Repeat the image */
  background-position: 0 0, 96px 96px; /* Offset second layer by 50% */
  animation: move-images 30s linear infinite; /* Infinite animation */
  z-index: -1; /* Place behind other content */
}

@keyframes move-images {
  0% {
    background-position: 0 0, 96px 96px;
  }
  100% {
    background-position: 96px 96px, 288px 288px; /* Move background to create seamless loop */
  }
}
</style>

history.content: Pull total number of "painting-" keys from Local Storage, count them, then output text "# / 15"

This function retrieves all keys from the Local Storage, filters out the keys that start with "painting-", and counts the number of these keys. The count is then formatted as a string in the format "# / 15", which is sent to the Outputs.CountText output. After the count is sent, the function signals that it has successfully completed by triggering the Outputs.Success output signal.
Run once per second

This function retrieves and counts keys from the local storage that start with "bugs-" every second. It defines a function called `getAndCountBugKeys` that retrieves all keys from the local storage, filters out the keys that start with "bugs-", and counts the number of these keys. The count is then formatted as "Bugs Progress: # / 40" and set as the Outputs.CountText output. After the count is set, the function signals the Outputs.Success output. The `getAndCountBugKeys` function is set to run every 1000 milliseconds (or one second) using the `setInterval` method.
on page load, play /audio/loading.mp3

This function plays an audio file when the node is triggered. It takes Inputs.AudioFile as an input, which is the path to the audio file. If no audio file is specified, it defaults to '/audio/loading.mp3'. The function creates a new Audio object with the specified file, and attempts to play it. If the audio file is successfully played, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If there is an error while trying to play the audio file, it sets the Outputs.Error output to the error message and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
on button pressed, play /audio/press.mp3

This function plays an audio file when a button is pressed. It takes Inputs.AudioFilePath and Inputs.OnButtonPressed as inputs. The Inputs.AudioFilePath is the path to the audio file to be played, and if it's not provided, it defaults to '/audio/press.mp3'. The Inputs.OnButtonPressed is a signal that is triggered when the button is pressed. When this signal is received, the function creates a new Audio object with the specified file path and plays the audio file. After the audio file is played, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal.
Change it so it plays when the script runs.

This function plays an audio file when the script runs. It takes Inputs.AudioFilePath as an input, which is the path to the audio file. If no path is provided, it defaults to '/audio/press.mp3'. It creates a new Audio object with the provided file path and attempts to play the audio file. If the audio file plays successfully, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If there's an error while trying to play the audio file, it logs the error to the console and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.

roots.label: Load and Pass-through Data with Checked State

history.content: Inputs: ID, Label, Checked, Outputs: ID, Label, Checked.  Function checks openDatabase 'MyAppDatabase' to find pre-existing object.  If it does not exist, this node will act as passthrough.  If it does exist, it will send existing.

This function checks if an object exists in a Web SQL Database named 'MyAppDatabase'. It takes Inputs.ID, Inputs.Label, and Inputs.Checked as inputs. It then opens the database and checks if an object with the given ID exists. If the object exists, it outputs the existing data through Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked and triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If the object does not exist, it acts as a passthrough, outputting the input data and triggering the Outputs.Failure output signal. In case of any errors during the transaction, it sets the Outputs.error output and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal. Please note that the Web SQL Database is a non-standard feature and it's not recommended for use in new projects. It's better to use IndexedDB instead.
in the case of failure, it should act as passthrough as well

This function checks if an object exists in a database and outputs the object's data if it exists. If the object does not exist or if there is an error, it acts as a passthrough and outputs the original inputs. The function takes three inputs: Inputs.ID, Inputs.Label, and Inputs.Checked. It opens a database named 'MyAppDatabase' and checks if an object with the given ID exists in the 'Objects' table. If the object exists, it outputs the object's ID, Label, and Checked status through Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked respectively, and triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If the object does not exist, it outputs the original inputs through Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal. In case of an error during the database transaction, it outputs the error through Outputs.error, acts as a passthrough by outputting the original inputs, and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.

It is not currently outputting anything.  It should be acting as passthrough due to error: Error in JS node run code. ReferenceError: openDatabase is not defined ReferenceError: openDatabase is not defined

The function is designed to interact with a database using the `openDatabase` function, which is part of the Web SQL Database specification. However, the `openDatabase` function is not defined, causing an error. Web SQL is no longer recommended for use, and if you're running this code in an environment where Web SQL is not supported, such as Node.js or modern browsers, you'll encounter this error. In such cases, you'll need to use a different method to interact with a database. For example, you could use the `sqlite3` package in Node.js or the IndexedDB API in a browser. The function takes Inputs.ID, Inputs.Label, and Inputs.Checked as inputs, and attempts to select a row from the "Objects" table in the database where the ID matches the input ID. If there's an error during this process, it sets the Outputs.error output to the error message, and the Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked outputs to their respective input values, and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal. If a matching row is found, it sets the Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked outputs to the values from the row, and triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If no matching row is found, it sets the Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked outputs to their respective input values, and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
Modify to have passthrough: id, Label, Price, Icon, Weather, Time, Months

This function loads data from the local storage and passes it through to the outputs. It takes several inputs: Inputs.ID, Inputs.Label, Inputs.Price, Inputs.Icon, Inputs.Weather, Inputs.Time, and Inputs.Months. If the data is found in the local storage, it is loaded and sent to the corresponding outputs. If the data is not found, the function passes through the input values to the outputs directly. The function triggers the Outputs.Success output signal if the data is successfully loaded from the local storage. If the data is not found in the local storage, it triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal and passes through the input values to the outputs.
Re-add the Checked functions how they were.  I still need those.

This function loads data from the local storage and passes it through to the outputs. If the data is not found in the local storage, it passes through the input values to the outputs. The function takes several inputs: Inputs.ID, Inputs.Label, Inputs.Price, Inputs.Icon, Inputs.Weather, Inputs.Time, Inputs.Months, and Inputs.Checked. The Inputs.Checked input is a boolean value indicating whether the item is checked or not. The function first loads the data from the local storage using the Inputs.ID as the key. If the data is found, it sets the outputs to the values found in the local storage. If the data is not found, it sets the outputs to the input values and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal. The function also handles the "Checked" state. If the data is found in the local storage, it sets the Outputs.Checked output to the value found in the local storage. If the data is not found, it sets the Outputs.Checked output to the Inputs.Checked input value. If the data loading is successful, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal.

The function takes Inputs.ID, Inputs.Label, and Inputs.Checked as inputs, and attempts to select a row from the "Objects" table in the database where the ID matches the input ID. If there's an error during this process, it sets the Outputs.error output to the error message, and the Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked outputs to their respective input values, and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal. If a matching row is found, it sets the Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked outputs to the values from the row, and triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If no matching row is found, it sets the Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked outputs to their respective input values, and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.

history.content: Pull total number of "painting-" keys from Local Storage, count them, then output text "# / 15"

This function retrieves all keys from the Local Storage, filters out the keys that start with "painting-", and counts the number of these keys. The count is then formatted as a string in the format "# / 15", which is sent to the Outputs.CountText output. After the count is sent, the function signals that it has successfully completed by triggering the Outputs.Success output signal.
Run once per second

This function retrieves and counts keys from the local storage that start with "bugs-" every second. It defines a function called `getAndCountBugKeys` that retrieves all keys from the local storage, filters out the keys that start with "bugs-", and counts the number of these keys. The count is then formatted as "Bugs Progress: # / 40" and set as the Outputs.CountText output. After the count is set, the function signals the Outputs.Success output. The `getAndCountBugKeys` function is set to run every 1000 milliseconds (or one second) using the `setInterval` method.
on button pressed, play /audio/press.mp3

This function plays an audio file when a button is pressed. It takes Inputs.AudioFilePath and Inputs.OnButtonPressed as inputs. The Inputs.AudioFilePath is the path to the audio file to be played, and if it's not provided, it defaults to '/audio/press.mp3'. The Inputs.OnButtonPressed is a signal that is triggered when the button is pressed. When this signal is received, the function creates a new Audio object with the specified file path and plays the audio file. After the audio file is played, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal.
Change it so it plays when the script runs.

This function plays an audio file when the script runs. It takes Inputs.AudioFilePath as an input, which is the path to the audio file. If no path is provided, it defaults to '/audio/press.mp3'. It creates a new Audio object with the provided file path and attempts to play the audio file. If the audio file plays successfully, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If there's an error while trying to play the audio file, it logs the error to the console and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.

history.content: Pull total number of "painting-" keys from Local Storage, count them, then output text "# / 15"

This function retrieves all keys from the Local Storage, filters out the keys that start with "painting-", and counts the number of these keys. The count is then formatted as a string in the format "# / 15", which is sent to the Outputs.CountText output. After the count is sent, the function signals that it has successfully completed by triggering the Outputs.Success output signal.
Run once per second

This function retrieves and counts keys from the local storage that start with "bugs-" every second. It defines a function called `getAndCountBugKeys` that retrieves all keys from the local storage, filters out the keys that start with "bugs-", and counts the number of these keys. The count is then formatted as "Bugs Progress: # / 40" and set as the Outputs.CountText output. After the count is set, the function signals the Outputs.Success output. The `getAndCountBugKeys` function is set to run every 1000 milliseconds (or one second) using the `setInterval` method.
on button pressed, play /audio/press.mp3

This function plays an audio file when a button is pressed. It takes Inputs.AudioFilePath and Inputs.OnButtonPressed as inputs. The Inputs.AudioFilePath is the path to the audio file to be played, and if it's not provided, it defaults to '/audio/press.mp3'. The Inputs.OnButtonPressed is a signal that is triggered when the button is pressed. When this signal is received, the function creates a new Audio object with the specified file path and plays the audio file. After the audio file is played, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal.
Change it so it plays when the script runs.

This function plays an audio file when the script runs. It takes Inputs.AudioFilePath as an input, which is the path to the audio file. If no path is provided, it defaults to '/audio/press.mp3'. It creates a new Audio object with the provided file path and attempts to play the audio file. If the audio file plays successfully, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If there's an error while trying to play the audio file, it logs the error to the console and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.

parameters.html:
<style>
body {
  margin: 0;
  height: 100vh;
  overflow: hidden;
  background: #8c96ee; /* Set background color */
  will-change: background-position; /* Hint to optimize rendering */
  position: relative; /* Ensure pseudo-element is positioned correctly */
}

body::before {
  content: "";
  position: absolute;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  right: 0;
  bottom: 0;
  background-image: 
    url('/images/background/bugs.png'),
    url('/images/background/bugs.png');
  background-size: 96px 96px; /* Size of the image */
  background-repeat: repeat; /* Repeat the image */
  background-position: 0 0, 96px 96px; /* Offset second layer by 50% */
  animation: move-images 30s linear infinite; /* Infinite animation */
  z-index: -1; /* Place behind other content */
}

@keyframes move-images {
  0% {
    background-position: 0 0, 96px 96px;
  }
  100% {
    background-position: 96px 96px, 288px 288px; /* Move background to create seamless loop */
  }
}
</style>

history.content: trigger repeater on page load

This function triggers a specified signal a number of times with a delay between each repetition when a page is loaded. The inputs for this function are Inputs.Repetitions, Inputs.Delay, Inputs.Signal, and Inputs.PageLoaded. If these inputs are not set, they will default to 5 repetitions, a delay of 1000 milliseconds, and a signal named 'Signal'. If the page is loaded, the function will repeat the signal for the specified number of repetitions with the specified delay between each repetition. After all repetitions are done, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If the page is not loaded, it triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
Pull total number of "painting-" keys from Local Storage, count them, then output text "# / 15"

This function retrieves all keys from the Local Storage, filters out the keys that start with "painting-", and counts the number of these keys. The count is then formatted as a string in the format "# / 15", which is sent to the Outputs.CountText output. After the count is sent, the function signals that it has successfully completed by triggering the Outputs.Success output signal.
Run once per second

This function retrieves and counts keys from the local storage that start with "bugs-" every second. It defines a function called `getAndCountBugKeys` that retrieves all keys from the local storage, filters out the keys that start with "bugs-", and counts the number of these keys. The count is then formatted as "Bugs Progress: # / 40" and set as the Outputs.CountText output. After the count is set, the function signals the Outputs.Success output. The `getAndCountBugKeys` function is set to run every 1000 milliseconds (or one second) using the `setInterval` method.

roots.label: Load and Pass-through Data with Checked State

history.content: Inputs: ID, Label, Checked, Outputs: ID, Label, Checked.  Function checks openDatabase 'MyAppDatabase' to find pre-existing object.  If it does not exist, this node will act as passthrough.  If it does exist, it will send existing.

This function checks if an object exists in a Web SQL Database named 'MyAppDatabase'. It takes Inputs.ID, Inputs.Label, and Inputs.Checked as inputs. It then opens the database and checks if an object with the given ID exists. If the object exists, it outputs the existing data through Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked and triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If the object does not exist, it acts as a passthrough, outputting the input data and triggering the Outputs.Failure output signal. In case of any errors during the transaction, it sets the Outputs.error output and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal. Please note that the Web SQL Database is a non-standard feature and it's not recommended for use in new projects. It's better to use IndexedDB instead.
in the case of failure, it should act as passthrough as well

This function checks if an object exists in a database and outputs the object's data if it exists. If the object does not exist or if there is an error, it acts as a passthrough and outputs the original inputs. The function takes three inputs: Inputs.ID, Inputs.Label, and Inputs.Checked. It opens a database named 'MyAppDatabase' and checks if an object with the given ID exists in the 'Objects' table. If the object exists, it outputs the object's ID, Label, and Checked status through Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked respectively, and triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If the object does not exist, it outputs the original inputs through Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal. In case of an error during the database transaction, it outputs the error through Outputs.error, acts as a passthrough by outputting the original inputs, and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.

It is not currently outputting anything.  It should be acting as passthrough due to error: Error in JS node run code. ReferenceError: openDatabase is not defined ReferenceError: openDatabase is not defined

The function is designed to interact with a database using the `openDatabase` function, which is part of the Web SQL Database specification. However, the `openDatabase` function is not defined, causing an error. Web SQL is no longer recommended for use, and if you're running this code in an environment where Web SQL is not supported, such as Node.js or modern browsers, you'll encounter this error. In such cases, you'll need to use a different method to interact with a database. For example, you could use the `sqlite3` package in Node.js or the IndexedDB API in a browser. The function takes Inputs.ID, Inputs.Label, and Inputs.Checked as inputs, and attempts to select a row from the "Objects" table in the database where the ID matches the input ID. If there's an error during this process, it sets the Outputs.error output to the error message, and the Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked outputs to their respective input values, and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal. If a matching row is found, it sets the Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked outputs to the values from the row, and triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If no matching row is found, it sets the Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked outputs to their respective input values, and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
Modify to have passthrough: id, Label, Price, Icon, Weather, Time, Months

This function loads data from the local storage and passes it through to the outputs. It takes several inputs: Inputs.ID, Inputs.Label, Inputs.Price, Inputs.Icon, Inputs.Weather, Inputs.Time, and Inputs.Months. If the data is found in the local storage, it is loaded and sent to the corresponding outputs. If the data is not found, the function passes through the input values to the outputs directly. The function triggers the Outputs.Success output signal if the data is successfully loaded from the local storage. If the data is not found in the local storage, it triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal and passes through the input values to the outputs.
Re-add the Checked functions how they were.  I still need those.

This function loads data from the local storage and passes it through to the outputs. If the data is not found in the local storage, it passes through the input values to the outputs. The function takes several inputs: Inputs.ID, Inputs.Label, Inputs.Price, Inputs.Icon, Inputs.Weather, Inputs.Time, Inputs.Months, and Inputs.Checked. The Inputs.Checked input is a boolean value indicating whether the item is checked or not. The function first loads the data from the local storage using the Inputs.ID as the key. If the data is found, it sets the outputs to the values found in the local storage. If the data is not found, it sets the outputs to the input values and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal. The function also handles the "Checked" state. If the data is found in the local storage, it sets the Outputs.Checked output to the value found in the local storage. If the data is not found, it sets the Outputs.Checked output to the Inputs.Checked input value. If the data loading is successful, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal.

parameters.html:
<style>
body {
  margin: 0;
  height: 100vh;
  overflow: hidden;
  background: #8c96ee; /* Set background color */
  will-change: background-position; /* Hint to optimize rendering */
  position: relative; /* Ensure pseudo-element is positioned correctly */
}

body::before {
  content: "";
  position: absolute;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  right: 0;
  bottom: 0;
  background-image: 
    url('/images/background/clothing.png'),
    url('/images/background/clothing.png');
  background-size: 96px 96px; /* Size of the image */
  background-repeat: repeat; /* Repeat the image */
  background-position: 0 0, 96px 96px; /* Offset second layer by 50% */
  animation: move-images 30s linear infinite; /* Infinite animation */
  z-index: -1; /* Place behind other content */
}

@keyframes move-images {
  0% {
    background-position: 0 0, 96px 96px;
  }
  100% {
    background-position: 96px 96px, 288px 288px; /* Move background to create seamless loop */
  }
}
</style>

history.content: trigger repeater on page load

This function triggers a specified signal a number of times with a delay between each repetition when a page is loaded. The inputs for this function are Inputs.Repetitions, Inputs.Delay, Inputs.Signal, and Inputs.PageLoaded. If these inputs are not set, they will default to 5 repetitions, a delay of 1000 milliseconds, and a signal named 'Signal'. If the page is loaded, the function will repeat the signal for the specified number of repetitions with the specified delay between each repetition. After all repetitions are done, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If the page is not loaded, it triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
Pull total number of "painting-" keys from Local Storage, count them, then output text "# / 15"

This function retrieves all keys from the Local Storage, filters out the keys that start with "painting-", and counts the number of these keys. The count is then formatted as a string in the format "# / 15", which is sent to the Outputs.CountText output. After the count is sent, the function signals that it has successfully completed by triggering the Outputs.Success output signal.
Run once per second

This function retrieves and counts keys from the local storage that start with "bugs-" every second. It defines a function called `getAndCountBugKeys` that retrieves all keys from the local storage, filters out the keys that start with "bugs-", and counts the number of these keys. The count is then formatted as "Bugs Progress: # / 40" and set as the Outputs.CountText output. After the count is set, the function signals the Outputs.Success output. The `getAndCountBugKeys` function is set to run every 1000 milliseconds (or one second) using the `setInterval` method.

roots.label: Load and Pass-through Data with Checked State

history.content: Inputs: ID, Label, Checked, Outputs: ID, Label, Checked.  Function checks openDatabase 'MyAppDatabase' to find pre-existing object.  If it does not exist, this node will act as passthrough.  If it does exist, it will send existing.

This function checks if an object exists in a Web SQL Database named 'MyAppDatabase'. It takes Inputs.ID, Inputs.Label, and Inputs.Checked as inputs. It then opens the database and checks if an object with the given ID exists. If the object exists, it outputs the existing data through Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked and triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If the object does not exist, it acts as a passthrough, outputting the input data and triggering the Outputs.Failure output signal. In case of any errors during the transaction, it sets the Outputs.error output and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal. Please note that the Web SQL Database is a non-standard feature and it's not recommended for use in new projects. It's better to use IndexedDB instead.
in the case of failure, it should act as passthrough as well

This function checks if an object exists in a database and outputs the object's data if it exists. If the object does not exist or if there is an error, it acts as a passthrough and outputs the original inputs. The function takes three inputs: Inputs.ID, Inputs.Label, and Inputs.Checked. It opens a database named 'MyAppDatabase' and checks if an object with the given ID exists in the 'Objects' table. If the object exists, it outputs the object's ID, Label, and Checked status through Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked respectively, and triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If the object does not exist, it outputs the original inputs through Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal. In case of an error during the database transaction, it outputs the error through Outputs.error, acts as a passthrough by outputting the original inputs, and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.

It is not currently outputting anything.  It should be acting as passthrough due to error: Error in JS node run code. ReferenceError: openDatabase is not defined ReferenceError: openDatabase is not defined

The function is designed to interact with a database using the `openDatabase` function, which is part of the Web SQL Database specification. However, the `openDatabase` function is not defined, causing an error. Web SQL is no longer recommended for use, and if you're running this code in an environment where Web SQL is not supported, such as Node.js or modern browsers, you'll encounter this error. In such cases, you'll need to use a different method to interact with a database. For example, you could use the `sqlite3` package in Node.js or the IndexedDB API in a browser. The function takes Inputs.ID, Inputs.Label, and Inputs.Checked as inputs, and attempts to select a row from the "Objects" table in the database where the ID matches the input ID. If there's an error during this process, it sets the Outputs.error output to the error message, and the Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked outputs to their respective input values, and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal. If a matching row is found, it sets the Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked outputs to the values from the row, and triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If no matching row is found, it sets the Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked outputs to their respective input values, and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
Modify to have passthrough: id, Label, Price, Icon, Weather, Time, Months

This function loads data from the local storage and passes it through to the outputs. It takes several inputs: Inputs.ID, Inputs.Label, Inputs.Price, Inputs.Icon, Inputs.Weather, Inputs.Time, and Inputs.Months. If the data is found in the local storage, it is loaded and sent to the corresponding outputs. If the data is not found, the function passes through the input values to the outputs directly. The function triggers the Outputs.Success output signal if the data is successfully loaded from the local storage. If the data is not found in the local storage, it triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal and passes through the input values to the outputs.
Re-add the Checked functions how they were.  I still need those.

This function loads data from the local storage and passes it through to the outputs. If the data is not found in the local storage, it passes through the input values to the outputs. The function takes several inputs: Inputs.ID, Inputs.Label, Inputs.Price, Inputs.Icon, Inputs.Weather, Inputs.Time, Inputs.Months, and Inputs.Checked. The Inputs.Checked input is a boolean value indicating whether the item is checked or not. The function first loads the data from the local storage using the Inputs.ID as the key. If the data is found, it sets the outputs to the values found in the local storage. If the data is not found, it sets the outputs to the input values and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal. The function also handles the "Checked" state. If the data is found in the local storage, it sets the Outputs.Checked output to the value found in the local storage. If the data is not found, it sets the Outputs.Checked output to the Inputs.Checked input value. If the data loading is successful, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal.

Inputs: ID, Label, Checked, Outputs: ID, Label, Checked.  Function checks openDatabase 'MyAppDatabase' to find pre-existing object.  If it does not exist, this node will act as passthrough.  If it does exist, it will send existing.

This function checks if an object exists in a Web SQL Database named 'MyAppDatabase'. It takes Inputs.ID, Inputs.Label, and Inputs.Checked as inputs. It then opens the database and checks if an object with the given ID exists. If the object exists, it outputs the existing data through Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked and triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If the object does not exist, it acts as a passthrough, outputting the input data and triggering the Outputs.Failure output signal. In case of any errors during the transaction, it sets the Outputs.error output and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal. Please note that the Web SQL Database is a non-standard feature and it's not recommended for use in new projects. It's better to use IndexedDB instead.
in the case of failure, it should act as passthrough as well

If the object does not exist or if there is an error, it acts as a passthrough and outputs the original inputs. The function takes three inputs: Inputs.ID, Inputs.Label, and Inputs.Checked. on page load, play /audio/loading.mp3

This function plays an audio file when the node is triggered. It takes Inputs.AudioFile as an input, which is the path to the audio file. If no audio file is specified, it defaults to '/audio/loading.mp3'. The function creates a new Audio object with the specified file, and attempts to play it. If the audio file is successfully played, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If there is an error while trying to play the audio file, it sets the Outputs.Error output to the error message and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
on button pressed, play /audio/press.mp3

This function plays an audio file when a button is pressed. It takes Inputs.AudioFilePath and Inputs.OnButtonPressed as inputs. The Inputs.AudioFilePath is the path to the audio file to be played, and if it's not provided, it defaults to '/audio/press.mp3'. The Inputs.OnButtonPressed is a signal that is triggered when the button is pressed. When this signal is received, the function creates a new Audio object with the specified file path and plays the audio file. After the audio file is played, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal.
Change it so it plays when the script runs.

This function plays an audio file when the script runs. It takes Inputs.AudioFilePath as an input, which is the path to the audio file. If no path is provided, it defaults to '/audio/press.mp3'. It creates a new Audio object with the provided file path and attempts to play the audio file. If the audio file plays successfully, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If there's an error while trying to play the audio file, it logs the error to the console and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.

history.content: Convert array of objects to array of strings

This function takes an array of objects from the Inputs.ObjectArray input, converts each object into a string using JSON.stringify, and outputs an array of these strings to the Outputs.StringArray output. If the input array is empty, it throws an error. If the operation is successful, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If any error occurs during the operation, it outputs the error to the Outputs.error output and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
I need StringArray to only have Labels and ObjectArray (a new one) that sends all unfiltered options

This function takes an array of objects from the Inputs.ObjectArray input, checks if the array is not empty, and then converts each object in the array to a string by extracting the 'Label' property from each object. The resulting array of strings is then outputted through the Outputs.StringArray output. The original unfiltered array of objects is also outputted through the Outputs.ObjectArray output. If the operation is successful, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If there's an error during the operation, it sets the Outputs.error output with the error message and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
Create new output "SavedSelection" to pass "Checked: True"

This function takes an array of objects from the Inputs.ObjectArray input, checks if the array is not empty, and then performs two operations on it. First, it converts each object in the array to a string using the 'Label' property of the object and stores these strings in a new array. This new array is then outputted through the Outputs.StringArray output. Second, it filters the input array to only include objects where the 'Checked' property is true. This filtered array is then outputted through the Outputs.SavedSelection output. The function also outputs the original unfiltered array of objects through the Outputs.ObjectArray output. If the function executes successfully, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If there's an error during the execution, it sets the Outputs.error output with the error message and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
Undo that last change

This function takes an array of objects from the Inputs.ObjectArray input, converts each object to a string, and outputs the new array of strings via the Outputs.StringArray output. It also filters the input array to only include objects where the property 'Checked' is true, and outputs this filtered array via the Outputs.SavedSelection output. The original unfiltered array of objects is output via the Outputs.ObjectArray output. If the operation is successful, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If there's an error during the operation, it sets the Outputs.error output with the error message and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.

roots.label: Extract Icon Strings from Object Array

history.content: Extract Icon strings from ObjectAray

This function extracts icon strings from an array of objects. It takes an array of objects as input through Inputs.ObjectArray. It then iterates over this array, extracting the 'icon' property from each object and storing these in a new array. The resulting array of icon strings is then output through Outputs.IconStrings. If the operation is successful, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If there's an error during the process, it sets the error message to the Outputs.error output and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
It's outputting Null when it should be outputting Icon's string

This function extracts the "icon" property values from an array of objects and outputs them as an array of strings. It takes an array of objects from the Inputs.ObjectArray input. It then checks if the array is not empty. If it is, it throws an error. Next, it maps through the array and for each object, it checks if the "icon" property exists. If it doesn't, it throws an error. If it does, it adds the value of the "icon" property to a new array. The function then outputs this new array of icon strings through the Outputs.IconStrings output and signals success through the Outputs.Success output. If there's an error at any point during the process, it outputs the error through the Outputs.error output and signals failure through the Outputs.Failure output.
The property we want is "Icons"

This function extracts the "Icons" property from an array of objects. It takes an array of objects as input through Inputs.ObjectArray. It then iterates over each object in the array, checks if the object has a property named "Icons", and if it does, it adds the value of the "Icons" property to a new array. The new array of icon strings is then output through Outputs.IconStrings. If the function successfully extracts the icon strings from all objects in the array, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If the input array is empty or if any object in the array does not have the "Icons" property, the function outputs an error message through Outputs.error and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
When updated data is received, all attached checkboxes should refresh.

This function extracts the checkbox states from an array of objects and assigns them to individual outputs. The function takes an array of objects from the Inputs.ObjectArray input. It then iterates over this array, checking each object for a property named "Checkbox". If this property exists and is not null, its value is added to a new array of checkbox states. If the property does not exist or is null, a default value of false is added to the array instead. The function then assigns the checkbox states to individual outputs, Outputs.CheckboxState1 through Outputs.CheckboxState15. If there are fewer than 15 objects in the input array, the remaining outputs are assigned a default value of false. If the function executes successfully, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If an error occurs during execution, the function catches the error, assigns its message to the Outputs.error output, sets all CheckboxState outputs to false, and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
I needed the images passed through like how i had it before, but I need it to also refresh so the icon is displayed, but I cannot refresh the whole page, just the checkbox nodes that were updated.

This function extracts the checkbox states from an array of objects and outputs each state to a separate output. It takes an array of objects from the Inputs.ObjectArray input, where each object is expected to have a "Checkbox" property. The function then maps through the array and extracts the checkbox states. The states are outputted to Outputs.CheckboxState1 through Outputs.CheckboxState15. If a checkbox state has changed, it triggers the corresponding Outputs.CheckboxStateChanged signal. If the function executes successfully, it triggers the Outputs.Success signal. If there's an error, it sets the Outputs.error output to the error message, sets all CheckboxState outputs to false (unchecked), and triggers the Outputs.Failure signal.
Please put my iconstrings back how they were as well.  I also need those.
I'm sorry, but your request is not clear. Could you please provide more details or context about the "iconstrings" you mentioned? This will help me assist you better.
I have replaced my code back how it was.  Do not remove Outputs.IconStrings.  I need a single output to tell an object to refresh visually to display the latest data.

This function extracts icon strings from an array of objects and assigns them to individual outputs. It takes an array of objects from the Inputs.ObjectArray input. For each object in the array, it checks if the object has a property "Icon". If it does, the function extracts the icon string; if it doesn't, it assigns a default icon string. The function then assigns these icon strings to individual outputs, from Outputs.IconStrings1 to Outputs.IconStrings15. If there are fewer than 15 objects in the array, the remaining outputs are assigned the default icon string. After successfully extracting and assigning all icon strings, the function triggers the Outputs.Success output signal and the Outputs.RefreshObject output signal, which can be used to tell an object to refresh visually to display the latest data. If there's an error during the process, the function assigns the default icon string to all IconStrings outputs, sets the Outputs.error output to the error message, and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.

history.content: Inputs: ID, Label, Checked, Outputs: ID, Label, Checked.  Function checks openDatabase 'MyAppDatabase' to find pre-existing object.  If it does not exist, this node will act as passthrough.  If it does exist, it will send existing.

This function checks if an object exists in a Web SQL Database named 'MyAppDatabase'. It takes Inputs.ID, Inputs.Label, and Inputs.Checked as inputs. It then opens the database and checks if an object with the given ID exists. If the object exists, it outputs the existing data through Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked and triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If the object does not exist, it acts as a passthrough, outputting the input data and triggering the Outputs.Failure output signal. In case of any errors during the transaction, it sets the Outputs.error output and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal. Please note that the Web SQL Database is a non-standard feature and it's not recommended for use in new projects. It's better to use IndexedDB instead.
in the case of failure, it should act as passthrough as well

This function checks if an object exists in a database and outputs the object's data if it exists. If the object does not exist or if there is an error, it acts as a passthrough and outputs the original inputs. The function takes three inputs: Inputs.ID, Inputs.Label, and Inputs.Checked. It opens a database named 'MyAppDatabase' and checks if an object with the given ID exists in the 'Objects' table. If the object exists, it outputs the object's ID, Label, and Checked status through Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked respectively, and triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If the object does not exist, it outputs the original inputs through Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal. In case of an error during the database transaction, it outputs the error through Outputs.error, acts as a passthrough by outputting the original inputs, and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.

It is not currently outputting anything.  It should be acting as passthrough due to error: Error in JS node run code. ReferenceError: openDatabase is not defined ReferenceError: openDatabase is not defined

The function is designed to interact with a database using the `openDatabase` function, which is part of the Web SQL Database specification. However, the `openDatabase` function is not defined, causing an error. Web SQL is no longer recommended for use, and if you're running this code in an environment where Web SQL is not supported, such as Node.js or modern browsers, you'll encounter this error. In such cases, you'll need to use a different method to interact with a database. For example, you could use the `sqlite3` package in Node.js or the IndexedDB API in a browser. The function takes Inputs.ID, Inputs.Label, and Inputs.Checked as inputs, and attempts to select a row from the "Objects" table in the database where the ID matches the input ID. If there's an error during this process, it sets the Outputs.error output to the error message, and the Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked outputs to their respective input values, and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal. If a matching row is found, it sets the Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked outputs to the values from the row, and triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If no matching row is found, it sets the Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked outputs to their respective input values, and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.

parameters.html:
<style>
body {
  margin: 0;
  height: 100vh;
  overflow: hidden;
  background: #7a3aaf; /* Set background color */
  will-change: background-position; /* Hint to optimize rendering */
  position: relative; /* Ensure pseudo-element is positioned correctly */
}

body::before {
  content: "";
  position: absolute;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  right: 0;
  bottom: 0;
  background-image: 
    url('/images/background/daily.png'),
    url('/images/background/daily.png');
  background-size: 96px 96px; /* Size of the image */
  background-repeat: repeat; /* Repeat the image */
  background-position: 0 0, 96px 96px; /* Offset second layer by 50% */
  animation: move-images 30s linear infinite; /* Infinite animation */
  z-index: -1; /* Place behind other content */
}

@keyframes move-images {
  0% {
    background-position: 0 0, 96px 96px;
  }
  100% {
    background-position: 96px 96px, 288px 288px; /* Move background to create seamless loop */
  }
}
</style>

}

history.content: Convert array of objects to array of strings

This function takes an array of objects from the Inputs.ObjectArray input, converts each object into a string using JSON.stringify, and outputs an array of these strings to the Outputs.StringArray output. If the input array is empty, it throws an error. If the operation is successful, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If any error occurs during the operation, it outputs the error to the Outputs.error output and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
I need StringArray to only have Labels and ObjectArray (a new one) that sends all unfiltered options

This function takes an array of objects from the Inputs.ObjectArray input, checks if the array is not empty, and then converts each object in the array to a string by extracting the 'Label' property from each object. The resulting array of strings is then outputted through the Outputs.StringArray output. The original unfiltered array of objects is also outputted through the Outputs.ObjectArray output. If the operation is successful, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If there's an error during the operation, it sets the Outputs.error output with the error message and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
Create new output "SavedSelection" to pass "Checked: True"

This function takes an array of objects from the Inputs.ObjectArray input, checks if the array is not empty, and then performs two operations on it. First, it converts each object in the array to a string using the 'Label' property of the object and stores these strings in a new array. This new array is then outputted through the Outputs.StringArray output. Second, it filters the input array to only include objects where the 'Checked' property is true. This filtered array is then outputted through the Outputs.SavedSelection output. The function also outputs the original unfiltered array of objects through the Outputs.ObjectArray output. If the function executes successfully, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If there's an error during the execution, it sets the Outputs.error output with the error message and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
Undo that last change

This function takes an array of objects from the Inputs.ObjectArray input, converts each object to a string, and outputs the new array of strings via the Outputs.StringArray output. It also filters the input array to only include objects where the property 'Checked' is true, and outputs this filtered array via the Outputs.SavedSelection output. The original unfiltered array of objects is output via the Outputs.ObjectArray output. If the operation is successful, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If there's an error during the operation, it sets the Outputs.error output with the error message and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.

roots.label: Extract Icon Strings from Object Array

history.content: Extract Icon strings from ObjectAray

This function extracts icon strings from an array of objects. It takes an array of objects as input through Inputs.ObjectArray. It then iterates over this array, extracting the 'icon' property from each object and storing these in a new array. The resulting array of icon strings is then output through Outputs.IconStrings. If the operation is successful, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If there's an error during the process, it sets the error message to the Outputs.error output and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
It's outputting Null when it should be outputting Icon's string

This function extracts the "icon" property values from an array of objects and outputs them as an array of strings. It takes an array of objects from the Inputs.ObjectArray input. It then checks if the array is not empty. If it is, it throws an error. Next, it maps through the array and for each object, it checks if the "icon" property exists. If it doesn't, it throws an error. If it does, it adds the value of the "icon" property to a new array. The function then outputs this new array of icon strings through the Outputs.IconStrings output and signals success through the Outputs.Success output. If there's an error at any point during the process, it outputs the error through the Outputs.error output and signals failure through the Outputs.Failure output.
The property we want is "Icons"

This function extracts the "Icons" property from an array of objects. It takes an array of objects as input through Inputs.ObjectArray. It then iterates over each object in the array, checks if the object has a property named "Icons", and if it does, it adds the value of the "Icons" property to a new array. The new array of icon strings is then output through Outputs.IconStrings. If the function successfully extracts the icon strings from all objects in the array, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If the input array is empty or if any object in the array does not have the "Icons" property, the function outputs an error message through Outputs.error and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
When updated data is received, all attached checkboxes should refresh.

This function extracts the checkbox states from an array of objects and assigns them to individual outputs. The function takes an array of objects from the Inputs.ObjectArray input. It then iterates over this array, checking each object for a property named "Checkbox". If this property exists and is not null, its value is added to a new array of checkbox states. If the property does not exist or is null, a default value of false is added to the array instead. The function then assigns the checkbox states to individual outputs, Outputs.CheckboxState1 through Outputs.CheckboxState15. If there are fewer than 15 objects in the input array, the remaining outputs are assigned a default value of false. If the function executes successfully, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If an error occurs during execution, the function catches the error, assigns its message to the Outputs.error output, sets all CheckboxState outputs to false, and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
I needed the images passed through like how i had it before, but I need it to also refresh so the icon is displayed, but I cannot refresh the whole page, just the checkbox nodes that were updated.

This function extracts the checkbox states from an array of objects and outputs each state to a separate output. It takes an array of objects from the Inputs.ObjectArray input, where each object is expected to have a "Checkbox" property. The function then maps through the array and extracts the checkbox states. The states are outputted to Outputs.CheckboxState1 through Outputs.CheckboxState15. If a checkbox state has changed, it triggers the corresponding Outputs.CheckboxStateChanged signal. If the function executes successfully, it triggers the Outputs.Success signal. If there's an error, it sets the Outputs.error output to the error message, sets all CheckboxState outputs to false (unchecked), and triggers the Outputs.Failure signal.
Please put my iconstrings back how they were as well.  I also need those.
I'm sorry, but your request is not clear. Could you please provide more details or context about the "iconstrings" you mentioned? This will help me assist you better.
I have replaced my code back how it was.  Do not remove Outputs.IconStrings.  I need a single output to tell an object to refresh visually to display the latest data.

This function extracts icon strings from an array of objects and assigns them to individual outputs. It takes an array of objects from the Inputs.ObjectArray input. For each object in the array, it checks if the object has a property "Icon". If it does, the function extracts the icon string; if it doesn't, it assigns a default icon string. The function then assigns these icon strings to individual outputs, from Outputs.IconStrings1 to Outputs.IconStrings15. If there are fewer than 15 objects in the array, the remaining outputs are assigned the default icon string. After successfully extracting and assigning all icon strings, the function triggers the Outputs.Success output signal and the Outputs.RefreshObject output signal, which can be used to tell an object to refresh visually to display the latest data. If there's an error during the process, the function assigns the default icon string to all IconStrings outputs, sets the Outputs.error output to the error message, and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.

roots.label: Save Multiple Inputs to Local Storage

history.content: 15 inputs that all individually save localstorage key "villagerdaily-0001" through "villagerdaily-0015".  This will save the "checked" state of 15 different checkboxes.

This function takes 15 inputs, Inputs.Input1 through Inputs.Input15, and saves each of them to local storage under keys 'villagerdaily-0001' through 'villagerdaily-0015'. If the process is successful, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If there's an error during the process, it sets the Outputs.error output with the error message and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
Wait one second, then play sound effect /audio/splash.mp3

This function plays a sound effect after a delay of one second. It uses the Inputs.setTimeout function to wait for 1 second, then creates a new audio object with the source '/audio/splash.mp3'. After creating the audio object, it plays the sound. Once the sound has been played, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal to indicate that the sound has been successfully played.
Add a 0.5 second timer with an output so I can navigate away after time.

This function waits for 1 second, then plays an audio file and signals a success. It also waits for 0.5 seconds, then signals to navigate away from the current page. The function uses the setTimeout method to create two timers. The first timer waits for 1 second, then creates a new audio object using the Audio constructor with '/audio/splash.mp3' as the input. It then plays the audio file and triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. The second timer waits for 0.5 seconds, then triggers the Outputs.NavigateAway output signal. This can be used to navigate away from the current page after a certain amount of time.

parameters.html:
<style>
body {
  margin: 0;
  height: 100vh;
  overflow: hidden;
  background: #8c96ee; /* Set background color */
  will-change: background-position; /* Hint to optimize rendering */
  position: relative; /* Ensure pseudo-element is positioned correctly */
}

body::before {
  content: "";
  position: absolute;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  right: 0;
  bottom: 0;
  background-image: 
    url('/images/background/fish.png'),
    url('/images/background/fish.png');
  background-size: 96px 96px; /* Size of the image */
  background-repeat: repeat; /* Repeat the image */
  background-position: 0 0, 96px 96px; /* Offset second layer by 50% */
  animation: move-images 30s linear infinite; /* Infinite animation */
  z-index: -1; /* Place behind other content */
}

@keyframes move-images {
  0% {
    background-position: 0 0, 96px 96px;
  }
  100% {
    background-position: 96px 96px, 288px 288px; /* Move background to create seamless loop */
  }
}
</style>

history.content: trigger repeater on page load

This function triggers a specified signal a number of times with a delay between each repetition when a page is loaded. The inputs for this function are Inputs.Repetitions, Inputs.Delay, Inputs.Signal, and Inputs.PageLoaded. If these inputs are not set, they will default to 5 repetitions, a delay of 1000 milliseconds, and a signal named 'Signal'. If the page is loaded, the function will repeat the signal for the specified number of repetitions with the specified delay between each repetition. After all repetitions are done, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If the page is not loaded, it triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
Pull total number of "painting-" keys from Local Storage, count them, then output text "# / 15"

This function retrieves all keys from the Local Storage, filters out the keys that start with "painting-", and counts the number of these keys. The count is then formatted as a string in the format "# / 15", which is sent to the Outputs.CountText output. After the count is sent, the function signals that it has successfully completed by triggering the Outputs.Success output signal.
Run once per second

This function counts the number of keys in the local storage that start with "fish-" and outputs the count in the format "Fish Progress: # / 40". The function, named `getFishKeys`, is run once every second (1000 milliseconds). It first retrieves all keys from the local storage, then filters out the keys that start with "fish-". The number of these keys is counted and the count is set as the Outputs.CountText output in the format "Fish Progress: # / 40". After the count is set, the function signals that it has successfully completed by triggering the Outputs.Success output.
Run on page load as well as once per second

This function counts the progress of a fish collection task. It retrieves all keys from the local storage, filters out the keys that start with "fish-", and counts the number of these keys. The count is then formatted as "Fish Progress: # / 40" and set as the Outputs.CountText. After this, the function signals a Outputs.Success. The function is set to run immediately when the page loads and then continues to run once every second, ensuring that the fish count is displayed as soon as the page is loaded and is updated every second.
Run on page load as well as once per second

This function counts the number of keys in the local storage that start with "fish-" and outputs the count in a specific format. The function, named getFishKeys, first retrieves all keys from the local storage. It then filters these keys to only include those that start with "fish-". The number of these "fish-" keys is then counted and this count is outputted in the format "Fish Progress: # / 40" through the Outputs.CountText output. After the count is outputted, the function signals that it has successfully completed its task by triggering the Outputs.Success output. This function is set to run once per second and also when the page loads.
on page load, play /audio/loading.mp3

This function plays an audio file when the node is triggered. It takes Inputs.AudioFile as an input, which is the path to the audio file. If no audio file is specified, it defaults to '/audio/loading.mp3'. The function creates a new Audio object with the specified file, and attempts to play it. If the audio file is successfully played, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If there is an error while trying to play the audio file, it sets the Outputs.Error output to the error message and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.

roots.label: Load and Pass-through Data with Checked State

history.content: Inputs: ID, Label, Checked, Outputs: ID, Label, Checked.  Function checks openDatabase 'MyAppDatabase' to find pre-existing object.  If it does not exist, this node will act as passthrough.  If it does exist, it will send existing.

This function checks if an object exists in a Web SQL Database named 'MyAppDatabase'. It takes Inputs.ID, Inputs.Label, and Inputs.Checked as inputs. It then opens the database and checks if an object with the given ID exists. If the object exists, it outputs the existing data through Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked and triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If the object does not exist, it acts as a passthrough, outputting the input data and triggering the Outputs.Failure output signal. In case of any errors during the transaction, it sets the Outputs.error output and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal. Please note that the Web SQL Database is a non-standard feature and it's not recommended for use in new projects. It's better to use IndexedDB instead.
in the case of failure, it should act as passthrough as well

This function checks if an object exists in a database and outputs the object's data if it exists. If the object does not exist or if there is an error, it acts as a passthrough and outputs the original inputs. The function takes three inputs: Inputs.ID, Inputs.Label, and Inputs.Checked. It opens a database named 'MyAppDatabase' and checks if an object with the given ID exists in the 'Objects' table. If the object exists, it outputs the object's ID, Label, and Checked status through Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked respectively, and triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If the object does not exist, it outputs the original inputs through Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal. In case of an error during the database transaction, it outputs the error through Outputs.error, acts as a passthrough by outputting the original inputs, and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.

It is not currently outputting anything.  It should be acting as passthrough due to error: Error in JS node run code. ReferenceError: openDatabase is not defined ReferenceError: openDatabase is not defined

The function is designed to interact with a database using the `openDatabase` function, which is part of the Web SQL Database specification. However, the `openDatabase` function is not defined, causing an error. Web SQL is no longer recommended for use, and if you're running this code in an environment where Web SQL is not supported, such as Node.js or modern browsers, you'll encounter this error. In such cases, you'll need to use a different method to interact with a database. For example, you could use the `sqlite3` package in Node.js or the IndexedDB API in a browser. The function takes Inputs.ID, Inputs.Label, and Inputs.Checked as inputs, and attempts to select a row from the "Objects" table in the database where the ID matches the input ID. If there's an error during this process, it sets the Outputs.error output to the error message, and the Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked outputs to their respective input values, and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal. If a matching row is found, it sets the Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked outputs to the values from the row, and triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If no matching row is found, it sets the Outputs.ID, Outputs.Label, and Outputs.Checked outputs to their respective input values, and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
Modify to have passthrough: id, Label, Price, Icon, Weather, Time, Months

This function loads data from the local storage and passes it through to the outputs. It takes several inputs: Inputs.ID, Inputs.Label, Inputs.Price, Inputs.Icon, Inputs.Weather, Inputs.Time, and Inputs.Months. If the data is found in the local storage, it is loaded and sent to the corresponding outputs. If the data is not found, the function passes through the input values to the outputs directly. The function triggers the Outputs.Success output signal if the data is successfully loaded from the local storage. If the data is not found in the local storage, it triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal and passes through the input values to the outputs.
Re-add the Checked functions how they were.  I still need those.

This function loads data from the local storage and passes it through to the outputs. If the data is not found in the local storage, it passes through the input values to the outputs. The function takes several inputs: Inputs.ID, Inputs.Label, Inputs.Price, Inputs.Icon, Inputs.Weather, Inputs.Time, Inputs.Months, and Inputs.Checked. The Inputs.Checked input is a boolean value indicating whether the item is checked or not. The function first loads the data from the local storage using the Inputs.ID as the key. If the data is found, it sets the outputs to the values found in the local storage. If the data is not found, it sets the outputs to the input values and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal. The function also handles the "Checked" state. If the data is found in the local storage, it sets the Outputs.Checked output to the value found in the local storage. If the data is not found, it sets the Outputs.Checked output to the Inputs.Checked input value. If the data loading is successful, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal.

Wait one second, then play sound effect /audio/splash.mp3

This function plays a sound effect after a delay of one second. It uses the Inputs.setTimeout function to wait for 1 second, then creates a new audio object with the source '/audio/splash.mp3'. After creating the audio object, it plays the sound. Once the sound has been played, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal to indicate that the sound has been successfully played.
Add a 0.5 second timer with an output so I can navigate away after time.

This function waits for 1 second, then plays an audio file and signals a success. It also waits for 0.5 seconds, then signals to navigate away from the current page. The function uses the setTimeout method to create two timers. The first timer waits for 1 second, then creates a new audio object using the Audio constructor with '/audio/splash.mp3' as the input. It then plays the audio file and triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. The second timer waits for 0.5 seconds, then triggers the Outputs.NavigateAway output signal. This can be used to navigate away from the current page after a certain amount of time.

parameters.html:
<style>
body {
  margin: 0;
  height: 100vh;
  overflow: hidden;
  background: #8c96ee; /* Set background color */
  will-change: background-position; /* Hint to optimize rendering */
  position: relative; /* Ensure pseudo-element is positioned correctly */
}

body::before {
  content: "";
  position: absolute;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  right: 0;
  bottom: 0;
  background-image: 
    url('/images/background/fossil.png'),
    url('/images/background/fossil.png');
  background-size: 96px 96px; /* Size of the image */
  background-repeat: repeat; /* Repeat the image */
  background-position: 0 0, 96px 96px; /* Offset second layer by 50% */
  animation: move-images 30s linear infinite; /* Infinite animation */
  z-index: -1; /* Place behind other content */
}

@keyframes move-images {
  0% {
    background-position: 0 0, 96px 96px;
  }
  100% {
    background-position: 96px 96px, 288px 288px; /* Move background to create seamless loop */
  }
}
</style>

history.content: trigger repeater on page load

This function triggers a specified signal a number of times with a delay between each repetition when a page is loaded. The inputs for this function are Inputs.Repetitions, Inputs.Delay, Inputs.Signal, and Inputs.PageLoaded. If these inputs are not set, they will default to 5 repetitions, a delay of 1000 milliseconds, and a signal named 'Signal'. If the page is loaded, the function will repeat the signal for the specified number of repetitions with the specified delay between each repetition. After all repetitions are done, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If the page is not loaded, it triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
Pull total number of "painting-" keys from Local Storage, count them, then output text "# / 15"

This function retrieves all keys from the Local Storage, filters out the keys that start with "painting-", and counts the number of these keys. The count is then formatted as a string in the format "# / 15", which is sent to the Outputs.CountText output. After the count is sent, the function signals that it has successfully completed by triggering the Outputs.Success output signal.
Run once per second

This function retrieves and counts keys from the local storage that start with "bugs-" every second. It defines a function called `getAndCountBugKeys` that retrieves all keys from the local storage, filters out the keys that start with "bugs-", and counts the number of these keys. The count is then formatted as "Bugs Progress: # / 40" and set as the Outputs.CountText output. After the count is set, the function signals the Outputs.Success output. The `getAndCountBugKeys` function is set to run every 1000 milliseconds (or one second) using the `setInterval` method.
on page load, play /audio/loading.mp3

This function plays an audio file when the node is triggered. It takes Inputs.AudioFile as an input, which is the path to the audio file. If no audio file is specified, it defaults to '/audio/loading.mp3'. The function creates a new Audio object with the specified file, and attempts to play it. If the audio file is successfully played, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If there is an error while trying to play the audio file, it sets the Outputs.Error output to the error message and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.

<style>
body {
  margin: 0;
  height: 100vh;
  overflow: hidden;
  background: #8c96ee; /* Set background color */
  will-change: background-position; /* Hint to optimize rendering */
  position: relative; /* Ensure pseudo-element is positioned correctly */
}

body::before {
  content: "";
  position: absolute;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  right: 0;
  bottom: 0;
  background-image: 
    url('/images/background/fruit.png'),
    url('/images/background/fruit.png');
  background-size: 96px 96px; /* Size of the image */
  background-repeat: repeat; /* Repeat the image */
  background-position: 0 0, 96px 96px; /* Offset second layer by 50% */
  animation: move-images 30s linear infinite; /* Infinite animation */
  z-index: -1; /* Place behind other content */
}

@keyframes move-images {
  0% {
    background-position: 0 0, 96px 96px;
  }
  100% {
    background-position: 96px 96px, 288px 288px; /* Move background to create seamless loop */
  }
}
</style>
